key_points: Senator Ron Johnson's demand to read aloud the 628-page COVID stimulus bill has delayed its passage.
The $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan includes $1,400 checks for individuals earning less than $75,000 and couples earning less than $150,000.
The package offers expanded unemployment benefits, state and local government aid, and funding for vaccination programs and school reopenings.
The full $1,400 payment phases out quicker than initially proposed, with no payment for individuals earning more than $80,000 and couples earning more than $160,000.
Around 11.4 million workers are at risk of losing their unemployment benefits between March 14 and April 11 without the bill's passage.
Democrats aim to pass the legislation before March 14 to avoid lapses in unemployment benefits.
Past stimulus payments provide a timeline reference: The CARES Act checks started arriving three weeks after its passage.
Timeline predictions for the third stimulus check suggest payments could start in the second half of March if the bill is passed by March 12.
Further changes to eligibility criteria and the IRS's tax season could complicate the distribution of the third round of checks.
Chris Krueger suggests eligible couples could receive their payment as early as the weekend of March 13 if the bill is passed and promptly signed.
